Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to make different nodes select different utxos, you can make them search the utxo list in a sorted order, offset by their msig id

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so first msig node would scan offset 0, N, 2*N, ..., 1, N+1, 2*N+1, ...

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: That is not a problem, for now there is only one withdraw at a time processed.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what do you mean by "sync the oraclfeed nodes so that there is no race condition"

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: But the problem is that for example the first sign that happens, 2 nodes take it at the same time and broadcast signtx. I want to sync them like that only one signs at the moment.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Before the first node that signed the tx broadcasted it to mempool and that tx reached 2nd node mempool, at that point other node thinks it needs to take the withdraw for signing.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: use the same idea

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: each node gets a msig id

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and each node only signs when the timestamp is id % N

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Hmmm, nice...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe 1 second is too fast, as the tx needs to propagate, if so, you can make it 2 seconds

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Yeah, so this would allow 30 nodes (which is enough) and each node can take id % N *2 second to process. Eventualy if some nodes are not live it could be that it will need 1 minute to sign it completely, but that is acceptable.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: And I would use the time from komodo (GetTime()) to check ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: assume all msig signing nodes have done ntp recently so they are in sync to the millisecond

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as long as each node can process multiple withdraws during their timeslot, it is all good

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we get a pipelined signing process with minimal collisions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: another way to avoid collisions is to add random sleeps

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and make sure to update state often so if a node sees another node did something, it wont do anything to contradict it

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Well, nodes will not process multiple withdraws as only one withdraw at the time is processed. But maybe we could expand it later with this idea to choose different utxos, and monitor which utxos are already used...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe a better way is to go as fast as possible, but wait for an earlier msig id to sign it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so at first second, msig.0 would be the only one that signs it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if he doesnt, then the next second msig,1 (and msig.0) are eligible to sign

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: etc.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once a single signature tx is seen, then the next msig.id is first to sign, the next second the next msig id is eligibile, etc.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think a tx will get M signatures in close to N seconds

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Yeah, maybe serialization is good. But how long should it wait until next msig.id takes for signing? msig.0 can be down...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 1 second

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if nothing appears, then msig.1 takes the lead

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: after 2 seconds if nothing, then msig.2 takes the lead

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then 3, 4, 5, ... to N-M

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is for the first signature

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then once there is a single signature tx in the mempool, the next msig.id has one second to sign and broadcast

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if not, then first+2, first+3, ... to N-M-1

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: now we have a 2 signature tx, so the msig.second+1 is eligible the first timeslot

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: second is the msig.id of the second signer

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Ok, but there is still a problem. If in 1st second msig.1 took the tx for signing and it broadcasted but it didn't propagate to msig.2 node in 2nd second msig.2 will take the initial withdraw to sign.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Basically if in 2 seconds it still doesn't propagate same will happen, but mostly it will be ok in 2 seconds.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: msig.3 would see both and then only pick one of the two, so maybe it is not a big issue?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: msig.2 would refrain from signing the first one, as it already signed it as the initial signer

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Ohhh

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Ok, get it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe there are some edge cases i dont see as this is just an intuitive design off the top of my head, but i think it should allow pretty decent practical performance

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: But it may be the issue with this. 1&2 sign the same and spend same input, 3 sees both and chooses 1, but 2 gets mined and 1 is invalid then...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if 1 and 2 sign the same one, then only one will be accepted by 3 into its mempool

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also, if each node is choosing utxo in an interleaved fashion, they wouldnt be choosing the same utxo

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let us imagine 1 and 2 both submit singly signed tx. now 3 will either accept 1 or 2, if it accepts 1, it will wait one second for 2 to sign it, but it wont happen and then it will sign it the next second

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it accepts 2, then it just immediately signs it

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: utxos cannot be chosen interleaved for siging. So when signing there is a marker which is spent in each signing iteration. So it must be serialezed.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: still the waiting for the signing time slot should resolve these tx signing forks

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: I think it may work. Let me try....

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if 3 and 4 have the same issue, then msig.5 would choose between 1+3 or 2+3 or 1+4 and 2+4

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, the same utxo can be accepted into all the mempools as it is a multisig

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, its the mempool on the assetchain!

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: No, it is not a multisig. The signing is regular!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so you can have a baton to get mutual exclusion

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: There are two types of utxos. The external utxos, and AC utxos.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: baton is basically marker

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: anyway, i think you have the idea of how to solve this now

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let me know if anything comes up that makes it not work so well

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: I'll try it. Thnx

Content: Signers will be notary opreators.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: not saying this is at all practical, just a bit curious about the math behind it now that I'm thinking about it. Given for example 60 signers, there are 386206920 subsets of 7 signers. Obviously you couldn't have this amount of addresses, but I'm trying to figure out how much more "coverage"(not sure what the term would be) we could get by having say 10 deposit multisigs.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content:
I don't get why you keep thinking about multiple msgi addresses? For one set of pubkeys you have one address. You don't get anything by having more addresses, it is still the same pubkeys.
What is your concern about 15 signers exactly?

Content: Am just brain storming, will take it elsewhere if you don't want to hear it

Content: again, `not saying this is at all practical` literally just curious about this math problem

Author: Alright#0419
Content: sorry, I know that's confusing ðŸ¤£

Content: eh never mind, don't let me waste your time
